5.05.text: >>Roberts: Handa ka na bang manumpa, Senador ?

8.99.text: >>Roberts: Ako, si Barack Hussein Obama, ay nanunumpa

12.44.text: >>Obama: Ako, si Barack Hussein Obama, ay nanunumpa

15.85.text: >>Roberts: na tutupdan ko ang opisina ng Pangulo sa Estados Unidos ng tapat

24.04.text: >>Roberts:  tapat ang opisina ng Pangulo ng Estados Unidos

26.03.text: >>Obama: ang opisina ng Pangulo ng Estados Unidos ng tapat

28.36.text: >>Roberts: at, sa lubos ng aking kakayahan

30.17.text: >>Obama: at, sa lubos ng aking kakayahan

31.69.text: >>Roberts:panatilihin, protektahan at ipagtanggol ang Saligang Batas ng Estados Unidos

35.69.text: >>panatilihin, protektahan at ipagtanggol ang Saligang Batas ng Estados Unidos

117.74.text: >>Feinstein: Malaking karangalan sa aking ipakilala sa inyo ang ika 44 na Pangulo ng Estados Unidos, eto si Barack Obama.

161.37.text: Nakatayo ako dito ngayon puno ng pagpapakumbaba sa

169.31.text: gawaing hinaharap natin, nagpapasalamat sa tiwalang ginawad,

174.31.text: randam ang sakripisyo ng ating mga ninuno.

178.50.text: Pinasasalamatan ko si Pangulong Bush sa kanyang

187.24.text: serbisyo sa ating bansa, ganun din sa pagbibigay

192.24.text: at kooperasyong pinakita nya sa proseso ng transisyon.

193.46.text: Apatnapu't apat nang Amerikano ang sumumpa bilang Pangulo.

200.53.text: Ang mga talumpati'y binigkas sa gitna ng tumataas na alon

205.53.text: ng kayamanan at  tahimik na tubig ng kapayapaan.

209.47.text: Ngunit, madalas din, na ang panunumpang ito'y

214.68.text: ginawa sa makulimlim na ulap at malakas na bagyo.

217.76.text: Sa mga pagkakataong ganito, nagpatuloy na sumulong ang Amerika di

223.72.text: lang dahil sa galing o pananaw ng mga nasa mataas na poder,

225.89.text: ngunit dahil Tayo ang Sambayanan ay nanatiling tapat sa mga adhikain ng ating mga

231.58.text: Tagapagtatag at masunurin sa mga dokumento ng Pagkakatatag.

239.86.text: Kaya't ganito dapat para sa henerasyong ito ng mga Amerikano.

244.07.text: Na nasa krisis tayo ngayo'y naiintindihan ng lahat.

249.07.text: Ang bayan natin ay nasa gitna ng digmaan,

253.45.text: laban sa malawak na alyansa ng karahasan at galit.

255.83.text: Our economy is badly weakened, a consequence of greed and irresponsibility

260.42.text: on the part of some, but also our collective failure to make hard choices

265.42.text: and prepare the nation for a new age.

269.37.text: Homes have been lost; jobs shed; businesses shuttered.

273.27.text: Our health care is too costly; our schools fail too many;

276.55.text: and each day brings further evidence

279.04.text: that the ways we use energy strengthen our adversaries

285.48.text: These are the indicators of crisis, subject to data and statistics.

292.79.text: Less measurable but no less profound is a sapping of confidence

297.93.text: across our land - a nagging fear that America's decline is inevitable,

304.24.text: and that the next generation must lower its sights.

309.24.text: Today I say to you that the challenges we face are real.

313.92.text: They are serious and they are many.

316.15.text: They will not be met easily or in a short span of time.

320.16.text: But know this, America - they will be met.

330.35.text: On this day, we gather because we have chosen hope over fear,

335.97.text: unity of purpose over conflict and discord.

340.97.text: On this day, we come to proclaim an end to the petty grievances

345.55.text: and false promises, the recriminations and worn out dogmas,

350.01.text: that for far too long have strangled our politics.

354.24.text: We remain a young nation, but in the words of Scripture,

359.24.text: the time has come to set aside childish things.

364.04.text: The time has come to reaffirm our enduring spirit;

367.82.text: to choose our better history; to carry forward that precious gift,

372.22.text: that noble idea, passed on from generation to generation:

375.99.text: the God-given promise that all are equal, all are free,

380.46.text: and all deserve a chance to pursue their full measure of happiness.

392.53.text: In reaffirming the greatness of our nation,

397.53.text: we understand that greatness is never a given.

403.44.text: Our journey has never been one of short cuts or settling for less.

407.57.text: It has not been the path for the faint-hearted -

410.58.text: for those who prefer leisure over work,

412.68.text: or seek only the pleasures of riches and fame.

417.23.text: Rather, it has been the risk-takers, the doers, the makers of things -

421.84.text: some celebrated but more often men and women obscure in their labor,

426.17.text: who have carried us up the long,

429.20.text: rugged path towards prosperity and freedom.

433.40.text: For us, they packed up their few worldly possessions and traveled

437.52.text: across oceans in search of a new life.

441.06.text: For us, they toiled in sweatshops and settled the West;

445.32.text: endured the lash of the whip and plowed the hard earth.

450.05.text: For us, they fought and died, in places like Concord

454.61.text: and Gettysburg, Normandy and Khe Sahn.

459.26.text: Time and again, these men and women struggled and sacrificed

463.16.text: and worked until their hands were raw so that we might live a better life.

468.13.text: They saw America as bigger than the sum of our individual ambitions;

472.52.text: greater than all the differences of birth or wealth or faction.

477.87.text: This is the journey we continue today.

481.30.text: We remain the most prosperous, powerful nation on Earth.

485.52.text: Our workers are no less productive than when this crisis began.

489.06.text: Our minds are no less inventive, our goods and services no less needed

493.29.text: than they were last week or last month or last year.

501.48.text: But our time of standing pat, of protecting narrow interests

505.89.text: and putting off unpleasant decisions - that time has surely passed.

511.06.text: Starting today, we must pick ourselves up, dust ourselves off,

515.79.text: and begin again the work of remaking America.

525.74.text: For everywhere we look, there is work to be done.

530.74.text: The state of our economy calls for action, bold and swift,

534.53.text: and we will act - not only to create new jobs,

537.48.text: but to lay a new foundation for growth.

540.45.text: We will build the roads and bridges, the electric grids and digital lines

544.41.text: that feed our commerce and bind us together.

548.06.text: We will restore science to its rightful place,

552.34.text: to raise health care's quality and lower its cost.

555.90.text: We will harness the sun and the winds and the soil

559.43.text: to fuel our cars and run our factories.

562.00.text: And we will transform our schools and colleges and universities

566.02.text: to meet the demands of a new age.

570.37.text: And all this we will do.

572.89.text: Now, there are some who question the scale of our ambitions -

579.34.text: who suggest that our system cannot tolerate too many big plans.

586.59.text: For they have forgotten what this country has already done;

590.85.text: what free men and women can achieve when imagination is joined

594.40.text: to common purpose, and necessity to courage.

599.37.text: What the cynics fail to understand is

601.71.text: that the ground has shifted beneath them -

604.14.text: that the stale political arguments that have consumed us

606.91.text: for so long no longer apply.

610.90.text: The question we ask today is not whether our government is too big

613.92.text: or too small, but whether it works - whether it helps families find jobs

618.38.text: at a decent wage, care they can afford, a retirement that is dignified.

623.38.text: Where the answer is yes, we intend to move forward.

627.59.text: Where the answer is no, programs will end.

631.26.text: And those of us who manage the public's dollars will be held to account -

635.35.text: to spend wisely, reform bad habits, and do our business in the light

639.92.text: of day - because only then can we restore the vital trust

643.87.text: between a people and their government.

648.30.text: Nor is the question before us whether the market is a force

654.90.text: Its power to generate wealth and expand freedom is unmatched,

659.13.text: but this crisis has reminded us that without a watchful eye,

663.07.text: the market can spin out of control - the nation cannot prosper long

668.06.text: when it favors only the prosperous.

670.66.text: The success of our economy has always depended not just on the size

675.27.text: of our Gross Domestic Product, but on the reach of our prosperity;

679.51.text: on the ability to extend opportunity to every willing heart -

684.03.text: not out of charity, but because it is the surest route to our common good.

695.65.text: As for our common defense, we reject as false the choice

701.57.text: between our safety and our ideals.

705.93.text: Our Founding Fathers, faced with perils that we can scarcely imagine,

712.26.text: drafted a charter to assure the rule of law and the rights of man,

717.26.text: a charter expanded by the blood of generations.

721.35.text: Those ideals still light the world,

723.93.text: and we will not give them up for expedience's sake.

729.42.text: And so to all the other peoples and governments who are watching today,

734.42.text: from the grandest capitals to the small village where my father was born:

738.67.text: know that America is a friend of each nation and every man, woman,

742.67.text: and child who seeks a future of peace and dignity,

746.00.text: and we are ready to lead once more.

764.22.text: Recall that earlier generations faced down fascism and communism not just

769.22.text: with missiles and tanks, but with the sturdy alliances

775.04.text: They understood that our power alone cannot protect us,

778.07.text: nor does it entitle us to do as we please.

780.74.text: Instead, they knew that our power grows through its prudent use;

785.42.text: our security emanates from the justness of our cause,

788.41.text: the force of our example, the tempering qualities

796.34.text: We are the keepers of this legacy.

798.92.text: Guided by these principles once more, we can meet those new threats

803.70.text: that demand even greater effort - even greater cooperation

809.47.text: We will begin to responsibly leave Iraq to its people,

812.40.text: and forge a hard-earned peace in Afghanistan.

816.83.text: With old friends and former foes,

818.67.text: we will work tirelessly to lessen the nuclear threat,

821.98.text: and roll back the specter of a warming planet.

825.92.text: We will not apologize for our way of life,

828.71.text: nor will we waver in its defense,

831.03.text: and for those who seek to advance their aims by inducing terror

834.44.text: and slaughtering innocents, we say to you now that our spirit is stronger

838.36.text: and cannot be broken; you cannot outlast us, and we will defeat you.

856.36.text: For we know that our patchwork heritage is a strength, not a weakness.

862.73.text: We are a nation of Christians and Muslims,

870.90.text: We are shaped by every language and culture,

873.52.text: drawn from every end of this Earth;

875.45.text: and because we have tasted the bitter swill of civil war and segregation,

880.07.text: and emerged from that dark chapter stronger and more united,

883.73.text: we cannot help but believe that the old hatreds shall someday pass;

887.47.text: that the lines of tribe shall soon dissolve;

890.98.text: that as the world grows smaller, our common humanity shall reveal itself;

894.86.text: and that America must play its role in ushering in a new era of peace.

899.44.text: To the Muslim world, we seek a new way forward,

904.81.text: based on mutual interest and mutual respect.

908.16.text: To those leaders around the globe who seek to sow conflict,

913.10.text: or blame their society's ills on the West -

915.46.text: know that your people will judge you

917.18.text: on what you can build, not what you destroy.

922.01.text: To those who cling to power through corruption and deceit and the silencing

930.38.text: of dissent, know that you are on the wrong side of history;

934.51.text: but that we will extend a hand if you are willing to unclench your fist.

939.50.text: To the people of poor nations, we pledge to work alongside you

947.00.text: to make your farms flourish and let clean waters flow;

950.53.text: to nourish starved bodies and feed hungry minds.

954.58.text: And to those nations like ours that enjoy relative plenty,

958.57.text: we say we can no longer afford indifference

963.55.text: nor can we consume the world's resources without regard to effect.

968.32.text: For the world has changed, and we must change with it.

974.73.text: As we consider the road that unfolds before us,

979.73.text: we remember with humble gratitude those brave Americans who,

984.05.text: at this very hour, patrol far-off deserts and distant mountains.

988.87.text: They have something to tell us, just as the fallen heroes who lie

995.13.text: in Arlington whisper through the ages.

999.36.text: We honor them not only because they are the guardians of our liberty,

1003.17.text: but because they embody the spirit of service;

1007.24.text: a willingness to find meaning in something greater than themselves.

1012.52.text: And yet, at this moment - a moment that will define a generation -

1018.51.text: it is precisely this spirit that must inhabit us all.

1024.32.text: For as much as government can do and must do, it is ultimately the faith

1029.91.text: and determination of the American people upon which this nation relies.

1034.87.text: It is the kindness to take in a stranger when the levees break,

1038.46.text: the selflessness of workers who would rather cut their hours

1041.80.text: than see a friend lose their job which sees us through our darkest hours.

1046.57.text: It is the firefighter's courage to storm a stairway filled with smoke,

1050.55.text: but also a parent's willingness to nurture a child,

1062.04.text: The instruments with which we meet them may be new.

1066.74.text: But those values upon which our success depends - honesty and hard work,

1072.69.text: courage and fair play, tolerance and curiosity,

1077.33.text: loyalty and patriotism - these things are old.

1089.51.text: They have been the quiet force of progress throughout our history.

1094.34.text: What is demanded then is a return to these truths.

1097.90.text: What is required of us now is a new era of responsibility - a recognition,

1104.50.text: on the part of every American, that we have duties to ourselves,

1107.60.text: our nation, and the world, duties that we do not grudgingly accept

1112.11.text: but rather seize gladly, firm in the knowledge that there is nothing

1115.92.text: so satisfying to the spirit, so defining of our character,

1120.75.text: than giving our all to a difficult task.

1124.38.text: This is the price and the promise of citizenship.

1128.91.text: This is the source of our confidence - the knowledge that God calls on us

1136.64.text: This is the meaning of our liberty and our creed - why men and women

1140.45.text: and children of every race and every faith can join in celebration

1144.65.text: across this magnificent mall, and why a man whose father less

1149.71.text: than sixty years ago might not have been served

1152.95.text: at a local restaurant can now stand before you to take a most sacred oath.

1168.34.text: So let us mark this day with remembrance,

1173.34.text: of who we are and how far we have traveled.

1178.12.text: In the year of America's birth, in the coldest of months,

1183.52.text: a small band of patriots huddled by dying campfires

1187.37.text: on the shores of an icy river.

1194.05.text: The snow was stained with blood.

1197.71.text: At a moment when the outcome of our revolution was most in doubt,

1202.31.text: the father of our nation ordered these words be read to the people:

1207.81.text: "Let it be told to the future world...that in the depth of winter,

1212.37.text: when nothing but hope and virtue could survive...that the city

1216.16.text: and the country, alarmed at one common danger, came forth to meet it."

1222.68.text: America. In the face of our common dangers, in this winter of our hardship,

1229.00.text: let us remember these timeless words.

1233.43.text: With hope and virtue, let us brave once more the icy currents,

1237.32.text: and endure what storms may come.

1240.50.text: Let it be said by our children's children

1242.88.text: that when we were tested we refused to let this journey end,

1246.70.text: that we did not turn back nor did we falter;

1249.64.text: and with eyes fixed on the horizon and God's grace upon us,

1253.89.text: we carried forth that great gift of freedom

1256.47.text: and delivered it safely to future generations.

1260.98.text: God bless you, and God bless the United States of America.
